summary_points: 1. Corteva, Inc.'s Annual Meeting of Stockholders on April 30, 2025, saw 608,290,106 shares voted, representing 89.05% of outstanding shares.
2.  All three proposals at the annual meeting (election of directors, advisory vote on executive compensation, and ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP) passed.
3.  No significant future impacts or risks are mentioned in this section of the filing.
1. F5, Inc. has $1,172.4 million remaining in its share repurchase program as of March 31, 2025, following a $1 billion authorization increase in October 2024.
2.  F5, Inc. anticipates recognizing 62.4% of its $1.9 billion in total non-cancelable performance obligations within the next year.
3. A second amended complaint was filed in the Lynwood Investment CY Limited lawsuit against F5, Inc. on April 7, 2025, with trial currently scheduled for November 1, 2027.
1. Zoetis Inc. faces a proposed $450 million additional tax liability from the IRS related to their 2018 tax return, unresolved as of May 6, 2025.
2.  In Q1 2025, Zoetis's revenue increased by 1% year-over-year to $2,220 million, while net income increased by 5% to $631 million.
3.  Zoetis completed the divestiture of its medicated feed additive product portfolio in October 2024 for a net purchase price of $309 million.
1. At Tyler Technologies' May 6, 2025 annual meeting, shareholders voted against a proposal regarding political spending by a margin of 27,154,449 votes against versus 9,718,107 votes for.

2.  Shareholders approved amendments to remove supermajority voting standards from Articles Ninth and Twelfth of the Restated Certificate of Incorporation, as well as an amendment to the written consent right, with substantial majorities.
3. Ernst & Young LLP was ratified as the independent auditor for fiscal year 2025, with 37,519,790 votes for versus 2,208,517 votes against.

1. Marathon Petroleum Corp. (MPC) reported a significant year-over-year decrease in Q1 2025 net income, from $937 million to a net loss of $74 million, primarily due to lower crack spreads in its Refining & Marketing segment.
2. MPC's share repurchases dropped considerably in Q1 2025, totaling 7 million shares ($1,057 million) compared to 13 million shares ($2,218 million) in Q1 2024.
3.  MPC faces ongoing climate-related lawsuits with potentially material, yet currently uncertain, liabilities.
1. Ball Corp.'s cash and cash equivalents decreased significantly by $464 million year-over-year to $467 million as of March 31, 2025.
2.  Ball Corp. anticipates a $75 million gain from the partial sale of its stake in Ball United Arab Can Manufacturing Company in the first half of 2025.
3. The outcome of Crown's appeal regarding patent infringement, heard on April 11, 2025, remains uncertain and could result in an unpredictable loss for Ball Corp.

1. Expeditors International reported first-quarter 2025 diluted net earnings attributable to shareholders per share increased 26% year-over-year to $1.47, with revenues increasing 21% to $2.7 billion.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Expeditors had 19,203 full-time equivalent employees, a year-over-year increase of 800 employees.

3.  While Q1 2025 results were strong,  future performance is unpredictable due to volatile air capacity and rates, potential impacts from ending the de minimis exemption, and significantly declining China to U.S. ocean volumes.
1. Marriott acquired the citizenM brand for $355 million (with potential additional payments of up to $110 million), but the acquisition is not yet complete as of May 6, 2025.
2. Marriott's effective tax rate significantly decreased to 13.0 percent in Q1 2025 compared to 22.4 percent in Q1 2024, primarily due to a release of tax reserves.
3.  Marriott anticipates a 5% net room growth for the full year 2025, including rooms from the citizenM acquisition.
1. Leidos Holdings, Inc. acquired a full-spectrum cyber company for $300 million, finalized on March 10, 2025.
2.  Revenue increased by 6.8% year-over-year to $4,245 million in the three months ended April 4, 2025.
3. As of April 4, 2025, Leidos had $17 billion in remaining performance obligations, with $11 billion expected to be recognized as revenue within the next 12 months.
1. Mettler-Toledo International Inc.'s annual stockholder meeting on May 1, 2025, saw the election of eight directors and ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor.
2.  At the May 1, 2025, meeting,  18,941,331 shares (out of 20,840,953 entitled to vote) were represented, exceeding the quorum requirement.
3.  Executive compensation received an advisory approval vote, with 15,902,548 votes for and 2,474,793 votes against.
1. Constellation Energy Corp.'s Q1 2025 net income decreased by $765 million year-over-year, primarily due to unrealized losses and the absence of nuclear PTC revenues.

2. The planned acquisition of Calpine Corporation, expected to close by June 1, 2026 at the latest, will cost $4.5 billion in cash, 50 million newly issued shares, and the assumption of $12.7 billion in debt.
3.  The ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict jeopardizes Constellation's nuclear fuel supply and costs, impacting future profitability.
1. AEP's Q1 2025 net income decreased by $203.5 million compared to Q1 2024,  a significant drop driven in part by the expiration of favorable tax benefits from 2024.
2. AEP plans to receive approximately $2.3 billion in net cash proceeds from forward sale agreements by December 31, 2026.
3.  Pending regulatory approvals for a 19.9% noncontrolling interest sale in OHTCo and IMTCo could negatively impact AEP’s future cash flows and financial condition.
1. Hershey Co. held its 2025 annual meeting on May 6, 2025.
2.  The presentation materials (Exhibit 99.1) from the annual meeting will not be incorporated into future filings.
3. The filing included three graphics related to the annual shareholder meeting.
1. Russell Torres was appointed President and Chief Operating Officer of Kimberly-Clark Corporation on May 1, 2025, with a base salary of $975,000 and a target bonus of 125% of his base salary.
2.  Under Mr. Torres' leadership since October 2024, Kimberly-Clark's North America business achieved mid-single-digit compound annual growth.
3.  A search is underway to find a permanent successor for the Interim President, North America, Kurt Laufer.

1. On May 1, 2025, Eastman Chemical Company eliminated the position of Executive Vice President, Methanolysis Operations and Worldwide Engineering and Construction Transformation, resulting in Steve Crawford's departure and a severance package of 52 weeks' base salary and up to four months of healthcare coverage.
2.  The 8-K filing indicates that as of May 1st 2025, Steve Crawford's departure was part of the company's ongoing succession planning.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are quantified in this section of the filing beyond the severance package provided to Mr. Crawford.
1. Align Technology, Inc. announced a new $1 billion stock repurchase program on May 6, 2025, following the completion of a prior $1 billion authorization.
2.  Align Technology projects a 5% to 15% year-over-year increase in clear aligner volume in 2025, with growth exceeding 15% projected for 2026-2028 and beyond.
3.  The company’s financial model forecasts Non-GAAP operating margins to reach approximately 22.5% in 2025, increasing to 23%–25% in 2026-2028 and exceeding 25% thereafter.
1. Uber Technologies, Inc. is acquiring an 85% stake in Trendyol GO, a Turkish online meal and grocery delivery business, for approximately $700 million.
2. Trendyol GO's gross bookings in 2024 were $2 billion, a more than 50% year-over-year increase from 2023.
3. The acquisition is expected to close in the second half of 2025 and is subject to regulatory approval; failure to obtain approval, or delays in obtaining it, pose a risk to the transaction.
1. Ball Corporation reported first-quarter 2025 total diluted earnings per share of 63 cents, a significant decrease from $11.61 in the first quarter of 2024.
2.  Global aluminum packaging shipments increased by 2.6% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024.
3. Ball Corporation expects comparable diluted earnings per share growth in the range of 11-14 percent for the year 2025.
1. Parker-Hannifin Corp. experienced significant year-over-year net sales decreases of $114 million for the quarter and $635 million for the nine months ending March 31, 2025.
2.  As of May 6, 2025, the company anticipates a total of $45 million in business realignment charges ($33 million already paid, $22 million remaining).
3.  There is a reasonably possible risk of up to a $30 million decrease in unrecognized tax benefits by May 6, 2026, impacting the effective tax rate.
1. Kevin M. Stein retired as President and Chief Executive Officer of TransDigm Group Incorporated, effective September 30, 2025, and will serve as an advisor until March 31, 2026.
2. Michael J. Lisman, the current Co-Chief Operating Officer, will succeed Mr. Stein as President and Chief Executive Officer.
3.  Mr. Stein's retirement and Mr. Lisman's promotion represent a planned leadership transition.
1. WEC Energy Group reported first-quarter 2025 net income of $724.2 million ($2.27 per share), a significant increase from $622.3 million ($1.97 per share) in the first quarter of 2024.
2. Natural gas deliveries in Wisconsin (excluding gas used for power generation) increased by 15.5% year-over-year in Q1 2025, although on a weather-normalized basis, they were 0.5% lower.
3.  The company reaffirmed its 2025 earnings guidance of $5.17 to $5.27 per share, contingent upon normal weather for the remainder of the year (as of May 6, 2025).
1. Global Payments Inc. retrospectively changed the classification of some cash flow activity from operating to financing in its GAAP statements.
2.  Q1 2025 adjusted EPS (including share-based compensation) increased by 11% year-over-year in constant currency to $2.69, exceeding the GAAP EPS increase of 2%.
3. The company maintains its 2025 outlook (as of May 6, 2025) of 10% to 11% constant currency adjusted EPS growth (excluding dispositions).
1. In the second quarter ended March 29, 2025, TransDigm Group reported net sales of $2,150 million, a 12% increase year-over-year.
2.  Year-to-date (twenty-six weeks ended March 29, 2025), net income increased by $186 million (23.7%) compared to the same period in 2024.

3. TransDigm Group reaffirmed its fiscal year 2025 financial guidance, although it revised its commercial OEM and defense market growth assumptions to reflect second-quarter results and current expectations.
1. IQVIA Holdings Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $3,829 million, a 2.5% increase year-over-year on a reported basis and 3.5% at constant currency.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, IQVIA's R&D Solutions contracted backlog was $31.5 billion, a 4.8% year-over-year increase.
3.  For full-year 2025, IQVIA raised its revenue guidance to $16,000–$16,400 million due to favorable foreign currency exchange rates, but reaffirmed its profit guidance.
1. ADM's first-quarter 2025 GAAP earnings per share were $0.61, a 57% decrease year-over-year, and adjusted EPS was $0.70, a 52% decrease.

2. Despite lower-than-expected first-quarter results, ADM reaffirmed its full-year 2025 adjusted EPS guidance of $4.00 to $4.75, but expects to deliver at the lower end of that range due to current market conditions.
3.  Ag Services & Oilseeds operating profit decreased by 52% year-over-year, primarily due to lower volumes and margins caused by tariff and trade policy uncertainty and increased industry capacity.
1. American Electric Power (AEP) reaffirmed its 2025 operating earnings (non-GAAP) guidance of $5.75 to $5.95 per share and its long-term growth rate of 6% to 8% on May 6, 2025.

2.  First-quarter 2025 GAAP earnings were $1.50 per share, a decrease of $0.41 compared to $1.91 per share in the first quarter of 2024; however, operating earnings increased to $1.54 per share from $1.27 per share in the same period.

3. AEP secured $2.82 billion in funding through a minority equity interest investment and a forward equity offering to meet its anticipated equity needs for its five-year, $54 billion capital investment plan, with the possibility of an additional $10 billion in investments over the next five years.
1. Zoetis Inc. reported Q1 2025 revenue of $2.2 billion, a 1% increase year-over-year, but organic operational revenue growth was 9% for the same period.
2.  Full-year 2025 revenue guidance was updated to $9.425 - $9.575 billion, reflecting foreign exchange impacts;  organic operational revenue growth guidance remains 6% to 8%.
3. Updated full-year 2025 guidance for organic operational growth in adjusted net income is 5% to 7%, lowered to reflect enacted tariffs.
1. In the first quarter of 2025, FIS reported a GAAP diluted EPS of $0.15, while adjusted EPS increased by 11% year-over-year to $1.21.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, FIS had $12.0 billion in outstanding debt.

3. FIS anticipates closing two strategic transactions (the sale of its Worldpay stake and the acquisition of Global Payments' Issuer Solutions business) simultaneously in the first half of 2026, resulting in pro forma gross leverage of approximately 3.4x, which they expect to reduce to their target of 2.8x within 18 months.

1. Marriott International's Q1 2025 worldwide RevPAR increased by 4.1 percent year-over-year, driven by higher ADR, with stronger growth in international markets (5.9 percent) compared to the U.S. & Canada (3.3 percent).
2.  The company's adjusted diluted EPS for Q1 2025 was $2.32, a slight increase compared to $2.13 in Q1 2024.
3. Marriott expects full-year 2025 net rooms growth to approach 5 percent, contingent on the successful acquisition of citizenM before the year's end.
1. Waters Corp's Q1 2025 net sales saw a 1% increase year-over-year after accounting for foreign currency translation impacts.
2.  Waters Corp. has a $1 billion share repurchase program authorization remaining as of May 6, 2025.
3.  The delayed implementation of US tariffs on imported goods until July 2025 could substantially affect Waters Corp.'s finances.
1. Constellation Energy's Q1 2025 GAAP net income per share decreased by $2.40 compared to Q1 2024.
2. The Calpine acquisition, expected to close in Q4 2025, is projected to increase adjusted operating earnings by over 20% in 2026 and contribute at least $2.00 per share annually through 2029.
3.  Despite lower-than-expected Q1 results, full-year 2025 adjusted operating earnings guidance remains unchanged at $8.90 to $9.60 per share (as of May 6, 2025).

1. Jacobs Solutions Inc. experienced a significant year-over-year decrease in net earnings, reporting a net loss of $(12.5) million in the first half of 2025 compared to $162.1 million in the first half of 2024.
2. As of March 28, 2025, $15.2 billion in remaining performance obligations were expected to generate 49% of revenue within the next 12 months, with the remainder spread over the next four years.

3.  The company anticipates a continued negative impact on its effective tax rate for the remainder of fiscal year 2025, with effective tax rates reaching 90.6% and 98.9% for the three and six months ended March 28, 2025, respectively.

1. Jacobs Solutions Inc. reported strong fiscal second-quarter 2025 results (ended March 28, 2025), including a 20% year-over-year backlog increase and a trailing twelve-month book-to-bill ratio of 1.3x.

2.  Despite a $109.5 million mark-to-market loss on its Amentum (AMTM) investment and negative impacts from an interim legal ruling, Jacobs' adjusted EPS for Q2 2025 was $1.43, up $0.26 year-over-year.

3.  The company reaffirmed its FY 2025 guidance, projecting mid-to-high single-digit adjusted net revenue growth over FY 2024, an adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.8%-14.0%, and an adjusted EPS range of $5.85-$6.20.
1. Marathon Petroleum Corp. reported a net loss of $(74) million for the first quarter of 2025, compared to a net income of $937 million in Q1 2024, primarily due to planned refinery maintenance.
2.  Refining & Marketing segment adjusted EBITDA decreased significantly year-over-year, from $1,986 million in Q1 2024 to $489 million in Q1 2025, driven by lower market crack spreads.

3.  The company plans capital expenditures of $100 million in 2025, $150 million in 2025 and $50 million in 2026, and $200 million in 2025 and a further $575 million in 2026 and 2027 for projects at its Los Angeles, Robinson, and Galveston Bay refineries respectively, aimed at improving competitiveness, optimizing jet fuel production, and upgrading distillates.

1. Waters Corporation reported first-quarter 2025 sales of $662 million, a 4% increase year-over-year (7% in constant currency), exceeding expectations and driven by strong instrument growth (11% in constant currency) in the Pharma and Industrial sectors.

2.  Full-year 2025 constant currency sales growth guidance was raised to +5.0% to +7.0%, and full-year non-GAAP EPS guidance was raised to $12.75 to $13.05, reflecting approximately +8% to +10% year-over-year growth ( +10% to +12% on a constant currency basis).

3.  Waters anticipates second-quarter 2025 constant currency sales growth in the range of +5.0% to +7.0% and non-GAAP EPS in the range of $2.88 to $2.98 (approximately +10% to +13% year-over-year growth, +12% to +15% in constant currency), while acknowledging risks associated with tariffs and policy changes, though they plan to mitigate these impacts.

1. Gartner experienced a significant decrease in US federal government contract value, falling from $275 million to $225 million between December 2024 and March 2025, with contract terminations totaling approximately $30 million.
2.  Gartner projects $2.9 billion in revenue from existing contracts for the remainder of 2025 (as of May 6th, 2025).
3.  Gartner expects to reclassify $8.7 million in losses from interest rate swaps into earnings during the remainder of 2025.
1. Gartner's Q1 2025 revenue was $1.5 billion, a 4.2% increase year-over-year (YoY) as reported and a 5.7% increase YoY when adjusted for foreign exchange.
2. Operating cash flow for Q1 2025 increased by 66% YoY to $314 million, while free cash flow increased by 73.3% YoY to $288 million.
3.  Gartner's full-year 2025 financial outlook was updated (as of May 6, 2025), though specific numbers are not provided in this excerpt.
1. Centene Corporation reaffirmed its 2025 full-year GAAP diluted earnings per share (EPS) guidance floor of >$6.19 and its full-year adjusted diluted EPS guidance floor of >$7.25 on May 6, 2025.
2.  The company's 8-K filing on May 6, 2025, indicates that senior management will meet with investors to discuss this guidance.

3. The filing includes numerous forward-looking statements regarding future performance, regulatory changes (e.g., Medicaid redeterminations and changes to the ACA), and various business risks that could materially affect results.
1. Leidos Holdings, Inc. reported strong first-quarter 2025 results (ended April 4, 2025), with revenues up 7% year-over-year to $4.25 billion and non-GAAP diluted EPS up 30% year-over-year to $2.97.
2.  The company revised its backlog policy in January 2025 to include estimated future revenue on sole-source IDIQ contracts, resulting in a reported backlog of $46.3 billion as of April 4, 2025.
3. Leidos is expected to complete the acquisition of a cyber platforms company in the second quarter of 2025 for a preliminary purchase price of $300 million.
1. Palantir's revenue surged 39% year-over-year to $883.9 million in the quarter ending March 31, 2025.
2.  A significant portion (47%) of Palantir's $1.9 billion in remaining performance obligations is expected to be recognized as revenue within the next year.
3. The *Cupat v. Palantir Technologies Inc.* lawsuit, dismissed in April 2025, is currently under appeal as of May 6, 2025.

1. At the April 30, 2025 annual meeting, Coterra Energy Inc. stockholders elected nine directors to serve until 2026 and approved, in a non-binding advisory vote, the compensation of named executive officers.
2.  Shareholder votes ranged from 562,674,575 "for" to 599,502,198 "for" for the election of individual directors, with "against" votes ranging from 871,674 to 47,006,565.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as the independent registered public accounting firm for the 2025 fiscal year, with 641,898,324 votes "for" and 36,247,479 votes "against".

1. Coterra Energy Inc. lowered its 2025 Permian Basin oil-directed rig count to seven from a planned ten, reducing capital expenditures by approximately $150 million due to macroeconomic uncertainty and oil price headwinds.

2.  Despite reduced oil-directed activity, Coterra increased its 2025 capital expenditures in the Marcellus Shale by $50 million (with a potential further increase of $50 million pending a third-quarter decision) and raised its full-year 2025 midpoint guidance for both barrels of oil equivalent (BOE) and natural gas production.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, Coterra had total debt outstanding of $4.25 billion and is prioritizing debt reduction in 2025 to retire outstanding term loans maturing in 2027 and 2028.
1. Celanese Corporation's Q1 2025 adjusted EPS of $0.57 significantly exceeded its guidance.
2. Celanese projects a substantial year-over-year increase in free cash flow to $700-$800 million in 2025 from $498 million in 2024.
3.  New tariffs are expected to negatively impact Engineered Materials free cash flow by approximately $60 million annually in the second half of 2025.

1. RTX Corp's 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareowners on May 1, 2025, resulted in the election of nine individuals to the board of directors, with Robert O. Work receiving significantly fewer "Votes For" (971,620,268) than other nominees.

2.  A shareowner proposal requesting a lobbying transparency report received only 135,400,139 "Votes For",  representing a small percentage of the 1,185,960,406 shares present at the meeting, indicating shareholder disapproval.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was appointed as RTX Corp's Independent Auditor for 2025,  a decision approved by a significant majority of shareholders.

1. Eastman Chemical Company's 2025 Annual Meeting on May 1, 2025, resulted in the election of ten directors, ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor, approval of executive compensation (advisory vote), and rejection of a proposal for an independent Board Chair (advisory vote).
2.  The proposal for an independent Board Chair received only 28,284,498 votes in favor, significantly less than the votes against (65,926,938).
3. As of May 1st, 2025, there were 115,459,908 shares of common stock outstanding, with 102,814,068 shares represented at the Annual Meeting.
1. LKQ Corp. amended its Credit Agreement on May 2, 2025, extending the maturity date of its unsecured term loan facility from January 5, 2026, to January 5, 2027.
2.  The filing mentions a waiver of specified events of default related to the company's failure to timely furnish copies of proposed amendments to its loan documents.

3.  The amendment to the Credit Agreement is conditional upon the absence of any defaults or events of default, and the accuracy of representations and warranties in the existing agreement as of May 2, 2025.
1. Celanese Corp reported a first-quarter 2025 U.S. GAAP diluted loss per share of $0.15, but adjusted earnings per share were $0.57, as of May 5th, 2025.
2.  The company's first-quarter 2025 net sales of $2.4 billion represent a 1% increase from the previous quarter, driven by a 2% volume increase, partially offset by currency fluctuations.

3. Celanese anticipates second-quarter 2025 adjusted earnings per share to be between $1.30 and $1.50, and projects free cash flow of $700 to $800 million for the full year 2025, though tariff impacts on demand create uncertainty.
1. On May 5, 2025, Paycom Software, Inc. declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $0.375 per share, payable on June 9, 2025, to stockholders of record as of May 27, 2025.
2. The filing is an 8-K Current Report filed with the SEC on May 5, 2025, indicating other events and financial statements.
3. No specific future impacts or risks, or regulatory/legal developments are mentioned in this section of the filing.

1. Vistra Corp. stockholders approved three amendments to the company's certificate of incorporation on April 30, 2025, including the removal of a 66 2/3% supermajority voting standard for amending certain provisions, replacing it with a simple majority.
2. At the 2025 Annual Meeting,  over 260 million votes were cast "for" each of the ten director candidates, compared to between 328,245 and 7,462,968 votes cast "against" each candidate.
3. A new 2025 Employee Stock Purchase Plan was approved, authorizing the issuance of up to 1,000,000 shares of common stock.
